article.description:
The New Orleans Hornets snapped their
five-game losing streak because the Chicago Bulls' struggles on the
road continued.
article.headline: Hornets end five-game losing streak
article.linkText: Hornets deal Bulls 18th straight road defeat
article.story:
NEW ORLEANS (AP) -- The New Orleans Hornets snapped their five-game losing streak because the Chicago Bulls' struggles on the road continued.
Wesley

Few of the Hornets expressed much satisfaction with how they played in their 90-83 victory on Friday night -- not even David Wesley, who scored a season-high 34 points. "We feel good that we broke our losing streak, but by no means is (Chicago) a good defensive team,'' Wesley said. "There were some lulls in there.'' New Orleans never trailed in the game, but twice nearly squandered leads of at least 17 points to Chicago, which has lost 18 straight road games since winning its season opener Oct. 30 at Boston. "We're still not where we should be. It's awfully tough when you're fighting to get wins,'' Hornets coach Paul Silas said. "We had a little defensive letdown. I don't care as long as we got a win.'' Jamal Magloire added 15 points and 14 rebounds, while Jamal Mashburn added 16 points for New Orleans as the Hornets (21-20) avoided falling below .500 for the first time this season. Jalen Rose scored 21 and Donyell Marshall had 14 points and 12 rebounds for Chicago. Eddie Robinson scored 13 and Marcus Fizer 12 off the bench for the Bulls. Rose scored 13 points in the fourth quarter to help Chicago reduce a 16-point deficit to five with two minutes left, but New Orleans made late free throws to keep the lead from eroding further. "The tough thing about coming back is that it takes so much energy to get every rebound, to get every loose ball, to try to get every stop, and when one or two things don't go your way, it puts you in a position to lose the game,'' Rose said. "I applaud our team's character for trying to fight back ... but at the same time, we've got to find a way to get out of the funk we're in on the road.'' Rose said Bulls coach Bill Cartwright may want to consider reshuffling the lineup. "Any time you're a young team ... the way we're playing, the reality of it is change is always an option,'' Rose said. Cartwright said the problem is with certain players, who he declined to name, trying to score too much. "Right now we have guys who are shooting more than they are supposed to,'' Cartwright said. "We have to have guys step up and take responsibility for the fact that they're not doing their jobs.'' New Orleans, which never trailed, led by as much as 70-50 late in the third quarter after Wesley hit a 3-pointer. New Orleans dominated the quarter, scoring 12 fast-break points. Wesley, who hit four 3-pointers for the game, scored 13 in the third quarter, several from inside with scrappy play or by leading the fast break. The Hornets' push inside came after New Orleans failed to make a field goal in the last 8:20 of a 90-82 loss to the Los Angeles Lakers on Wednesday night. "It's a conscious effort by all of us to not settle for jump shots so much, especially late,'' Wesley said. Baron Davis, who played for the second-straight game after sitting out six straight with back spasms, hit a soaring one-handed shot as New Orleans built up its lead in the third quarter. Davis was visibly in pain but wanted to play as the Hornets tried to snap their losing streak. He finished with eight points. The Bulls came out like the team that has been struggling on the road, with four turnovers and two missed shots in their first seven possessions. Looking relaxed and fluid, the Hornets hit 13 of their first 20 shots. Mashburn hit four of his first five, Wesley hit his first two and Magloire hit his first five, including a finger roll that put New Orleans ahead 28-12 with more than two minutes still left in the first quarter. "My teammates got me the ball in spots where I could dunk it or do something with it, and when I'm that close to the basket it's hard to stop,'' Magloire said. Cartwright, visibly annoyed at the lackluster effort early on, went with a reserve lineup much of the second quarter. Fizer's inside basket capped a 22-6 run by the Bulls that pulled Chicago within 35-34 in the second quarter. New Orleans finally settled down and exchanged several baskets with the Bulls until Wesley hit a 3-pointer to put New Orleans up 43-39 at halftime. Game notes
Wesley has scored at least 30 points twice this season. He has surpassed 20 points in four of the Hornets' last seven games and has scored in double figures in 19 of 21 games. ... The Hornets have won 16 of their last 18 games against Chicago ... Chicago's bench outscored the Hornets' reserves 40-13. The Bulls came in getting an average of about 35 points from their reserves.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
